Dynamic Clustering and Power Control for Two-Tier Wireless Federated Learning

Abstract

Federated learning (FL) has been recognized as a promising distributed learning paradigm to support intelligent applications at the wireless edge, where a global model is trained iteratively through the collaboration of the edge devices without sharing their data. However, due to the relatively large communication cost between the devices and parameter server (PS), direct computing based on the information from the devices may not be resource efficient. This paper studies the joint communication and learning design for the over-the-air computation (AirComp)-based two-tier wireless FL scheme, where the lead devices first collect the local gradients from their nearby subordinate devices, and then send the merged results to the PS for the second round of aggregation. We establish a convergence result for the proposed scheme and derive the upper bound on the optimality gap between the expected and optimal global loss values. Next, based on the device distance and data importance, we propose a hierarchical clustering method to build the two-tier structure. Then, with only the instantaneous channel state information (CSI), we formulate the optimality gap minimization problem and solve it by using an efficient alternating minimization method. Numerical results show that the proposed scheme outperforms the baseline ones.

Index Terms:
Federated learning (FL), joint communication and learning design, over-the-air computation (AirComp), hierarchical clustering, multi-tier computing.

I Introduction

With the proliferation of the mobile edge devices (such as smart phones, wearable devices, and sensors), a massive amount of data has been generated at the network edge[1]. The recent progresses in machine learning (ML) techniques [2, 3], fueled by the rich data, have the potential to enable a wide range of intelligence applications at the wireless edge networks, such as intelligent health [4] and autonomous driving [5]. However, conventional ML model training methods are conducted in a centralized fashion, which requires the central server to aggregate high volume raw data obtained at the edge devices and thus inevitably causes data privacy concerns [6]. Besides, collecting a large amount of raw data to implement the centralized learning methods in wireless scenarios inevitably consumes too much resources [7], and thus it is hardly practical to be employed at the wireless edge [8]. To overcome the aforementioned challenges, federated learning (FL) [9, 10, 11] has been proposed as a promising distributed ML paradigm to protect the local data privacy and relieves the communication burden by allowing the edge devices to train the ML model locally and only upload their local gradients to the parameter server (PS) without sharing their data [12, 13, 14].

Despite the above advantages of FL, deploying FL in wireless scenarios requires a large number of high-dimensional gradients and global model exchanges between the PS and the edge devices, which still suffer from the communication bottleneck, especially for the case with large number of edge devices [15]. To address this issue, over-the-air computation (AirComp) technique has been introduced to the wireless FL systems to support concurrently gradient uploading from the edge devices over the shared radio resources by exploiting the waveform-superposition nature of the wireless multiple access channels (MAC) [16, 17]. Despite the advantages of reducing the communication latency and enhancing the scalability of the wireless FL systems, AirComp-based gradient aggregation suffers from the distortion caused by the additive noise and channel fading of the wireless channels, which significantly degrades the FL performance [18], and comprehensive studies have been conducted to tackle this issue [19, 20, 21, 22, 23]. In [19], the authors proposed a joint device selection and receiver beamforming to maximize the number of the selected devices in each iteration under the mean square error (MSE) constraint for the aggregated signals. The authors in [20] proposed a joint transmit power and de-noising factor optimization method to minimize the per-iteration gradient aggregation error by taking the gradient statistic into account. In [21], the authors proposed the one-bit gradient quantization scheme at the transmitters and the AirComp majority-voting based decoding at the receiver, and analyzed the effect of noise, channel fading, and channel estimation errors on the FL performance in terms of convergence rate. In [22], the authors proposed an optimal transmit power allocation to minimize the expected optimality gap of the wireless FL system for both the cases with biased and unbiased gradient aggregations. In [23], the authors proposed a joint device selection and transmit power design to accelerate the convergence rate of the wireless FL system for both the convex and non-convex loss function cases.

The results shown in the above researches exhibit quite similar solutions to combat the negative effects of the additive noise and channel fading, where they discard the stragglers, i.e., the devices with relatively weak channel gains, due to the limited transmit power budget. However, discarding certain amount of devices during the training process may degrade the performance of the wireless FL systems due to the insufficient training data exploitation [24]. Therefore, to fully exploit all the available data, one possible solution is to apply multi-tier computing techniques into the wireless FL systems, which is able to enhance the stragglers’ access probability to the PS and has been reported to show better learning performance compared to the conventional FL structure with direct communications between the devices and the PS [25, 26, 27, 28, 29, 30]. In [25], the authors studied the digital two-tier relay-assisted FL framework and proposed a partially synchronized parallel scheme to simultaneously transmit the gradients from the edge devices to relays and models from relays to the PS, which is able to reduce the training time. In [26], the authors proposed a two-tier relay-assisted AirComp-based wireless FL scheme, and optimized the transmit power coefficients at the devices and relays and the de-noising factors at the PS by minimizing the MSE of the aggregated signals with alternating minimization method. Instead of introducing additional relays, the authors [27] proposed a cluster-based two-tier wireless FL scheme based on the method proposed in [21], where they select a set of devices as relays in each cluster to aggregate the gradients from the devices within the same cluster and the selected devices upload the aggregated gradients based on AirComp. The results in [27] numerically showed that the proposed scheme achieves comparable learning performance to the ideal FL system without channel fading and additive noise. However, the aforementioned works only considered device selection for the proposed scheme without providing any convergence analysis, power control, or clustering design for the proposed scheme. In [28], the authors investigated the gradient sparsification and periodic averaging for the two-tier wireless FL system, where devices transmit the sparsified gradients to the associated small-cell base station (SBS) for intermediate model updates and the SBSs transmit the updated models to the macro based station (MBS) after several intermediate model updates. In [29], the authors investigated a two-tier client-edge-cloud wireless FL system, where the devices upload the model parameters to the associated edge servers after multiple local updates and the edge servers upload the updated model parameters to the cloud server after several model aggregations. The authors in [29] analyzed the convergence of the proposed two-tier FL scheme and revealed the impact of the number of the local updates and edge aggregations on the convergence. In [30], the authors investigated the energy efficient resource allocation for a similar two-tier wireless FL systems as in [28, 29], where the devices upload the gradients to the middle-tier aggregators and the middle-tier aggregators upload the aggregated gradients immediately to the top-tier aggregator. However, none of above works considered the joint communication and learning design, i.e., analytically characterizing the impact of communications on the learning performance, and some of them focus on only the communication aspect [25, 26, 27] and the others only for the learning aspect [28, 29, 30].

This paper proposes an joint communication and learning design for an AirComp-based two-tier wireless FL scheme, which dynamically divides all the devices into different clusters across different training iterations. In particular, the subordinate devices transmit their local gradients to their associated lead device within the same cluster and all the lead devices transmit their aggregated gradients to the PS through AirComp. The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows.

  1. 1.

    We analyze the convergence behavior of the considered FL scheme and derive the optimality gap between the expected and optimal global loss values, which is applicable to any clustering scheme and characterize the impact of the AirComp-based two-tier gradient aggregation errors, in terms of their bias and MSE, on the optimality gap.

  2. 2.

    We propose a hierarchical clustering method by adopting the minimax linkage criterion to dynamically divides the devices into a given number of clusters. In particular, we incorporate the device distance, which affects the communication aspect, and the data importance, which affects the learning performance. Then, the lead device in each cluster is selected by jointly considering its location within the corresponding cluster, its distance to the PS, and its data importance.

  3. 3.

    With the given cluster result and the instantaneous channel state information (CSI), we formulate the optimality gap minimization problem with respect to (w.r.t) the transmit power at the devices and de-noising factor at the PS. We propose an efficient algorithm based on alternating optimization to solve this problem, where the closed-form solutions for all sub optimization problems in each iteration are derived.

The reminder of this paper is organized as follows. Section II presents the system model. Section III provides the convergence analysis results and quantifies the impact of the gradient aggregation errors on the optimality gap. Section IV proposes the clustering scheme and develops an efficient alternating minimization method to solve the optimality gap minimization problem. Numerical results are presented in Section V. Finally, Section VI concludes this paper.

II System Model

This paper introduces the AirComp-based two-tier wireless FL scheme to solve problem (1) in an iterative fashion. As shown in Fig. 1, during the t𝑡t-th iteration, the main idea of the proposed scheme is that we apply a clustering method to divide the all the devices into N𝑁N different clusters 𝒞1(t),⋯,𝒞N(t)superscriptsubscript𝒞1𝑡⋯superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑁𝑡\mathcal{C}_{1}^{(t)},\cdots,\mathcal{C}_{N}^{(t)}, where cluster 𝒞n(t)superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑛𝑡\mathcal{C}_{n}^{(t)} contains Cn(t)=|𝒞n(t)|superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑛𝑡C_{n}^{(t)}=|\mathcal{C}_{n}^{(t)}| devices with K=∑n=1NCn(t)𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑛𝑡K=\sum_{n=1}^{N}C_{n}^{(t)} and N𝑁N is constant across different iterations, and then one lead device is selected in each cluster to perform intra-cluster gradient aggregation and the PS performs inter-cluster gradient aggregation through AirComp. Specifically, the considered scheme consecutively executes the following four steps during the t𝑡t-th iteration:

  1. 1.

    Model boradcasting: The PS broadcasts the global model 𝐰(t)superscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}^{(t)} and all devices can successfully download the global model 𝐰(t)superscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}^{(t)}.

    Therefore, (17) can be rewritten as

    𝐰(t+1)=𝐰(t)−γ​(𝐠¯(t)+𝜺(t)).superscript𝐰𝑡1superscript𝐰𝑡𝛾superscript¯𝐠𝑡superscript𝜺𝑡\mathbf{w}^{(t+1)}=\mathbf{w}^{(t)}-\gamma(\bar{\mathbf{g}}^{(t)}+\bm{\varepsilon}^{(t)}). (21)
Remark 1.

Unlike many existing literatures [18, 23], which do not consider the gradient normalization or directly measure the learning performance by aggregation error w.r.t. the normalized symbol 𝐬k(t)superscriptsubscript𝐬𝑘𝑡\mathbf{s}_{k}^{(t)} [19, 20, 26], we take both the normalization and de-normalization steps (9) and (4) into account, and explicitly compute the aggregation error 𝛆(t)superscript𝛆𝑡\bm{\varepsilon}^{(t)} (4) w.r.t. the gradients 𝐠k(t)superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑡\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(t)}. Hence, with the derived aggregation error 𝛆(t)superscript𝛆𝑡\bm{\varepsilon}^{(t)}, we are able to analyze the impact of the AirComp-based two-tier gradient aggregations on the convergence behavior of the wireless FL algorithm as detailed in Section III-B.

III Convergence Analysis

In this section, we analyze the convergence behavior of the considered AirComp-based two-tier wireless FL algorithm presented in Section II for the general smooth non-convex learning problems. We first present the preliminaries, and then present the theoretical results on convergence for the AirComp-based two-tier wireless FL algorithm in terms of the optimality gap between the expected and optimal global loss values.

III-A Preliminaries

First, we make the following standard assumptions that are commonly adopted in the convergence analysis in the literature [32, 15, 21, 22].

Assumption 1 (Smoothness).

The global loss function defined in (2) is differentiable and the gradient is uniformly Lipschitz continuous with a positive Lipschitz constant L𝐿L, i.e., ∀𝐯,𝐰∈ℝdfor-all𝐯𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\forall\mathbf{v},\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

‖∇F​(𝐯)−∇F​(𝐰)‖2≤L​‖𝐯−𝐰‖2,subscriptnorm∇𝐹𝐯∇𝐹𝐰2𝐿subscriptnorm𝐯𝐰2\|\nabla F(\mathbf{v})-\nabla F(\mathbf{w})\|_{2}\leq L\|\mathbf{v}-\mathbf{w}\|_{2}, (22)

which is equivalent to

F​(𝐯)≤F​(𝐰)+(𝐯−𝐰)T​∇F​(𝐰)+L2​‖𝐯−𝐰‖22.𝐹𝐯𝐹𝐰superscript𝐯𝐰𝑇∇𝐹𝐰𝐿2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐯𝐰22F(\mathbf{v})\leq F(\mathbf{w})+(\mathbf{v}-\mathbf{w})^{T}\nabla F(\mathbf{w})+\frac{L}{2}\|\mathbf{v}-\mathbf{w}\|_{2}^{2}. (23)
Assumption 2 (Bounded Variance).

The obtained local gradient 𝐠ksubscript𝐠𝑘\mathbf{g}_{k} is an independent and unbiased estimation for the full-batch gradient ∇F​(𝐰)∇𝐹𝐰\nabla F(\mathbf{w}) with element-wise bounded variance, i.e.,

𝔼​[𝐠k]=∇F​(𝐰),∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequence𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐠𝑘∇𝐹𝐰for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{g}_{k}]=\nabla F(\mathbf{w}),\ \forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (24)
𝔼[(gk[m]−∇F(w[m])2]≤δm2mb,∀k∈𝒦,1≤m≤M,\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[(g_{k}[m]-\nabla F(w[m])^{2}]\leq\frac{\delta_{m}^{2}}{m_{b}},\ \forall k\in\mathcal{K},1\leq m\leq M, (25)

where gk​[m]subscript𝑔𝑘delimited-[]𝑚g_{k}[m] and ∇F​(w​[m])∇𝐹𝑤delimited-[]𝑚\nabla F(w[m]) are the m𝑚m-th element of 𝐠ksubscript𝐠𝑘\mathbf{g}_{k} and ∇F​(𝐰)∇𝐹𝐰\nabla F(\mathbf{w}), respectively, 𝛅=[δ1,⋯,δM]𝛅subscript𝛿1⋯subscript𝛿𝑀\bm{\delta}=[\delta_{1},\cdots,\delta_{M}] is a non-negative constant vector.

III-B Convergence Results

Based on Assumptions 1 and 2 and the recasted global model (21), we are ready to present the convergence result in the following theorem.

Theorem 1.

Consider the scenarios when Assumptions 1 and 2 are valid and set the learning rate γ<12​L𝛾12𝐿\gamma<\frac{1}{2L}, the optimality gap between the expected and optimal global loss function values is upper bounded by

𝔼​[F​(𝐰(T+1))]−F∗𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝐰𝑇1superscript𝐹\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[F(\mathbf{w}^{(T+1)})\right]-F^{*} (26)
≤\displaystyle\leq ηT​𝔼​[F​(𝐰(1))−F∗]+∑t=1TηT−t​L​γ2mb​‖𝜹‖22+∑t=1TηT−t​(γ2​‖𝔼​[𝜺(t)]‖22+L​γ2​𝔼​[‖𝜺(t)‖22])superscript𝜂𝑇𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝐰1superscript𝐹superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscript𝜂𝑇𝑡𝐿superscript𝛾2subscript𝑚𝑏superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜹22superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscript𝜂𝑇𝑡𝛾2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝜺𝑡22𝐿superscript𝛾2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝜺𝑡22\displaystyle\eta^{T}\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{w}^{(1)})-F^{*}]+\sum_{t=1}^{T}\eta^{T-t}\frac{L\gamma^{2}}{m_{b}}\|\bm{\delta}\|_{2}^{2}+\sum_{t=1}^{T}\eta^{T-t}\left(\frac{\gamma}{2}\left\|\mathbb{E}\left[\bm{\varepsilon}^{(t)}\right]\right\|_{2}^{2}+L\gamma^{2}\mathbb{E}\left[\|\bm{\varepsilon}^{(t)}\|_{2}^{2}\right]\right)

where η=2​L2​γ2−L​γ+1𝜂2superscript𝐿2superscript𝛾2𝐿𝛾1\eta=2L^{2}\gamma^{2}-L\gamma+1, T𝑇T is the total training iterations, 𝐰(1)superscript𝐰1\mathbf{w}^{(1)} is the initial global model, and F∗superscript𝐹F^{*} is the optimal loss function value.

Proof:

Please see Appendix. A. ∎

Remark 2.

The optimality gap derived in the right hand side (RHS) of (26) consists of four terms related to the initial gap 𝔼​[F​(𝐰(1))−F∗]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝐰1superscript𝐹\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{w}^{(1)})-F^{*}], the gradient variance L​γ2mb​‖𝛅‖22𝐿superscript𝛾2subscript𝑚𝑏superscriptsubscriptnorm𝛅22\frac{L\gamma^{2}}{m_{b}}\|\bm{\delta}\|_{2}^{2}, and the AirComp-based two-tier gradient aggregation error γ2​‖𝔼​[𝛆(t)]‖22+L​γ2​𝔼​[‖𝛆(t)‖22]𝛾2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝛆𝑡22𝐿superscript𝛾2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝛆𝑡22\frac{\gamma}{2}\left\|\mathbb{E}\left[\bm{\varepsilon}^{(t)}\right]\right\|_{2}^{2}+L\gamma^{2}\mathbb{E}\left[\|\bm{\varepsilon}^{(t)}\|_{2}^{2}\right]. Given the learning rate γ<12​L𝛾12𝐿\gamma<\frac{1}{2L}, we have 0<η=2​L2​γ2−L​γ+1<10𝜂2superscript𝐿2superscript𝛾2𝐿𝛾110<\eta=2L^{2}\gamma^{2}-L\gamma+1<1. Hence, as T→∞→𝑇T\rightarrow\infty, the first term ηT​𝔼​[F​(𝐰(1))−F∗]superscript𝜂𝑇𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝐰1superscript𝐹\eta^{T}\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{w}^{(1)})-F^{*}] diminishes to zero. If we further choose the learning rate sufficiently small, the rest terms in the RHS of (26) can also diminish to zero. In this case, the wireless FL converges exactly to the optimal point. However, in practice, neither T𝑇T can go to infinity nor the learning rate is always small enough, which makes the wireless FL end up to a point in the neighborhood of the optimal point when terminated. Besides, 𝔼​[𝛆(t)]𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝛆𝑡\mathbb{E}\left[\bm{\varepsilon}^{(t)}\right] and 𝔼​[‖𝛆(t)‖22]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝛆𝑡22\mathbb{E}\left[\|\bm{\varepsilon}^{(t)}\|_{2}^{2}\right] in (26) are the bias and MSE of the globally aggregated gradient at the t𝑡t-th iteration, respectively, where the expectations are taken w.r.t. the channel noise. Obviously, the squared bias ‖𝔼​[𝛆(t)]‖22superscriptsubscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝛆𝑡22\|\mathbb{E}\left[\bm{\varepsilon}^{(t)}\right]\|_{2}^{2} and MSE 𝔼​[‖𝛆(t)‖22]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝛆𝑡22\mathbb{E}\left[\|\bm{\varepsilon}^{(t)}\|_{2}^{2}\right] are both determined by the transmit power values βkn(t)superscriptsubscript𝛽subscript𝑘𝑛𝑡\beta_{k_{n}}^{(t)} and αk~n(t)superscriptsubscript𝛼subscript~𝑘𝑛𝑡\alpha_{\tilde{k}_{n}}^{(t)} and de-noising factor ζ(t)superscript𝜁𝑡\zeta^{(t)} with given cluster results {𝒞1(t),⋯,𝒞N(t)}superscriptsubscript𝒞1𝑡⋯superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑁𝑡\{\mathcal{C}_{1}^{(t)},\cdots,\mathcal{C}_{N}^{(t)}\} at the t𝑡t-th iteration.

Remark 3.

The convergence result obtained in Theorem (1) is a quite general result for the considered two-tier wireless FL scheme satisfying Assumptions 1-2, as long as we can compute the aggregation error w.r.t. the gradients 𝐠k(t)superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑡\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(t)} as (21). Hence, Theorem 1 is applicable to any clustering result and power and de-noising factor allocation across in the whole training process.

IV Clustering and Optimality Gap Minimization

In this section, we first introduce the distance and data importance aware dynamic cluster method to all divide the devices into several clusters at different iterations. Then, we present the joint transmit power and de-nosing factor control to minimize the derived optimality gap (26).

IV-A Distance and Data Importance Aware Clustering

To cluster the devices, we adopt the hierarchical clustering method with the minimax linkage criterion [33, 34]. However, conventional clustering methods only consider the distances between the devices to determine how to group all the devices into multiple clusters. In our proposed scheme, we further incorporate the data importance to the clustering objectives such that both the communication and the learning performance can be considered for the considered scheme. Let Ik(t)superscriptsubscript𝐼𝑘𝑡I_{k}^{(t)} denote the data importance for the k𝑘k-th device at the t𝑡t-th iteration, which is measured in different ways for various learning tasks [35, 36]. In this paper, we focus on the learning task of training convolutional neural network (CNN) models for image classification. In this case, a suitable measure for the date importance is entropy, which is computed as [37, 38, 39]

Ik(t)=−1Dk​∑i∈𝒟k∑y¯k,i∈𝒴ℙ𝐰(t)​(y¯k,i|𝐱k,i)​log⁡ℙ𝐰(t)​(y¯k,i|𝐱k,i),superscriptsubscript𝐼𝑘𝑡1subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑖subscript𝒟𝑘subscriptsubscript¯𝑦𝑘𝑖𝒴subscriptℙsuperscript𝐰𝑡conditionalsubscript¯𝑦𝑘𝑖subscript𝐱𝑘𝑖subscriptℙsuperscript𝐰𝑡conditionalsubscript¯𝑦𝑘𝑖subscript𝐱𝑘𝑖I_{k}^{(t)}=-\frac{1}{D_{k}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{D}_{k}}\sum_{\bar{y}_{k,i}\in\mathcal{Y}}\mathbb{P}_{\mathbf{w}^{(t)}}(\bar{y}_{k,i}|\mathbf{x}_{k,i})\log\mathbb{P}_{\mathbf{w}^{(t)}}(\bar{y}_{k,i}|\mathbf{x}_{k,i}), (27)

where y¯k,isubscript¯𝑦𝑘𝑖\bar{y}_{k,i} is the prediction label for data input 𝐱k,isubscript𝐱𝑘𝑖\mathbf{x}_{k,i}, 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y} is the set of all labels, and ℙ𝐰(t)​(y¯k|𝐱k,i)subscriptℙsuperscript𝐰𝑡conditionalsubscript¯𝑦𝑘subscript𝐱𝑘𝑖\mathbb{P}_{\mathbf{w}^{(t)}}(\bar{y}_{k}|\mathbf{x}_{k,i}) is the prediction probability of input 𝐱k,isubscript𝐱𝑘𝑖\mathbf{x}_{k,i} and output y¯k,isubscript¯𝑦𝑘𝑖\bar{y}_{k,i} with given model parameter 𝐰(t)superscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}^{(t)}. Note that Ik(t)superscriptsubscript𝐼𝑘𝑡I_{k}^{(t)} in (27) is non-negative, and the larger Ik(t)superscriptsubscript𝐼𝑘𝑡I_{k}^{(t)} is, the more important for the data at the device k𝑘k to update the model 𝐰(t)superscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}^{(t)}.

Let 𝚍𝚒𝚜𝚝​(⋅,⋅):ℝ2×ℝ2→ℝ:𝚍𝚒𝚜𝚝⋅⋅→superscriptℝ2superscriptℝ2ℝ\mathtt{dist}(\cdot,\cdot):\mathbb{R}^{2}\times\mathbb{R}^{2}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} be the Euclidean distance between any two devices, and let 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} be a set of points in ℝ2superscriptℝ2\mathbb{R}^{2}, i.e., the locations of the devices in 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K}. We then define the following concepts [34]:

Definition 1.

(Distance of a point in a set) The distance of point pi∈𝒫subscript𝑝𝑖𝒫p_{i}\in\mathcal{P} in the set 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} is defined as r​(pi,𝒫)=maxpj∈𝒫⁡𝚍𝚒𝚜𝚝​(pi,pj)𝑟subscript𝑝𝑖𝒫subscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗𝒫𝚍𝚒𝚜𝚝subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑝𝑗r(p_{i},\mathcal{P})=\max_{p_{j}\in\mathcal{P}}\mathtt{dist}(p_{i},p_{j}).

Definition 2.

(Minimax distance of a set) The minimax distance of the set 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} is defined as r​(𝒫)=minpi∈𝒫⁡r​(pi,𝒫)𝑟𝒫subscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝒫𝑟subscript𝑝𝑖𝒫r(\mathcal{P})=\min_{p_{i}\in\mathcal{P}}r(p_{i},\mathcal{P}).

Definition 3.

(Joint distance and data importance objective) The joint distance and data importance objective of of a set 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} is defined as 𝚘𝚋𝚓​(𝒫)=r​(𝒫)+ϱ​maxpi∈𝒫⁡Ipi(t)𝚘𝚋𝚓𝒫𝑟𝒫italic-ϱsubscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝒫superscriptsubscript𝐼subscript𝑝𝑖𝑡\mathtt{obj}(\mathcal{P})=r(\mathcal{P})+\varrho\max_{p_{i}\in\mathcal{P}}I_{p_{i}}^{(t)}, where ϱitalic-ϱ\varrho is a coefficient to balance the distance and data importance.

Definition 4.

(Minimax linkage) The minimax linkage between two sets of points 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} and 𝒫2subscript𝒫2\mathcal{P}_{2} in ℝ2superscriptℝ2\mathbb{R}^{2} is defined as 𝚕𝚒𝚗𝚔​(𝒫1,𝒫2)=𝚘𝚋𝚓​(𝒫1∪𝒫2)𝚕𝚒𝚗𝚔subscript𝒫1subscript𝒫2𝚘𝚋𝚓subscript𝒫1subscript𝒫2\mathtt{link}(\mathcal{P}_{1},\mathcal{P}_{2})=\mathtt{obj}(\mathcal{P}_{1}\cup\mathcal{P}_{2}).

Following the similar procedure to Algorithm 1 in [34] by utilizing the proposed the minimax linkage in Definition 4, we can efficiently divide the devices into N𝑁N clusters. After the clusters being formed, we need to further determine the lead device for each cluster. Specifically, in cluster 𝒞n(t)superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑛𝑡\mathcal{C}_{n}^{(t)}, let Din(t)superscriptsubscript𝐷subscript𝑖𝑛𝑡D_{i_{n}}^{(t)} denote the average distance between the device insubscript𝑖𝑛i_{n} and all the rest devices within the same cluster, i.e.,

Din(t)=1Cn(t)−1​∑jn∈𝒞n(t),jn≠in𝚍𝚒𝚜𝚝​(pjn,pin),in∈𝒞n(t),formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝐷subscript𝑖𝑛𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑛𝑡1subscriptformulae-sequencesubscript𝑗𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑛𝑡subscript𝑗𝑛subscript𝑖𝑛𝚍𝚒𝚜𝚝subscript𝑝subscript𝑗𝑛subscript𝑝subscript𝑖𝑛subscript𝑖𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑛𝑡D_{i_{n}}^{(t)}=\frac{1}{C_{n}^{(t)}-1}\sum_{j_{n}\in\mathcal{C}_{n}^{(t)},j_{n}\neq i_{n}}\mathtt{dist}(p_{j_{n}},p_{i_{n}}),\ i_{n}\in\mathcal{C}_{n}^{(t)}, (28)

and let D^in(t)superscriptsubscript^𝐷subscript𝑖𝑛𝑡\hat{D}_{i_{n}}^{(t)} denote the distance between device insubscript𝑖𝑛i_{n} to the PS. Then, the lead client knsubscript𝑘𝑛k_{n} in cluster 𝒞n(t)superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑛𝑡\mathcal{C}_{n}^{(t)} is chosen according to the following rule:

kn=arg⁡minin∈𝒞n(t)⁡Din(t)+ϱ1​D^in(t)+ϱ2​Iin(t),subscript𝑘𝑛subscriptsubscript𝑖𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐷subscript𝑖𝑛𝑡subscriptitalic-ϱ1superscriptsubscript^𝐷subscript𝑖𝑛𝑡subscriptitalic-ϱ2superscriptsubscript𝐼subscript𝑖𝑛𝑡k_{n}=\arg\min_{i_{n}\in\mathcal{C}_{n}^{(t)}}D_{i_{n}}^{(t)}+\varrho_{1}\hat{D}_{i_{n}}^{(t)}+\varrho_{2}I_{i_{n}}^{(t)}, (29)

where ϱ1subscriptitalic-ϱ1\varrho_{1} and ϱ2subscriptitalic-ϱ2\varrho_{2} are the coefficients to balance the device’s location in the cluster, distance to the PS, and data importance.

IV-B Optimality Gap Minimization

In this subsection, we consider the transmit power and de-noising factor control to minimize the optimality gap derived in Theorem 1 to enhance the learning performance of the considered scheme. Hence, we summarize the alternating minimization method for solving problem (34) in Algorithm 1. As problems (35), (39), and (46) are optimally solved, it is easy to show that objective values f(i)superscript𝑓𝑖f^{(i)} are non-increasing over iterations. Hence, the convergence of Algorithm 1 is guaranteed.

Based on the above analysis, the proposed AirComp-based two-tier wireless FL scheme is summarized in Algorithm 2.

V Numerical Results

V-A Simulation setup

Here, we model all the channel coefficients as distance-dependent Rayleigh fading channels [43, 42] as hk~n,kn(t)=Ω0​dk~n,kn−κ​h0superscriptsubscriptℎsubscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝑘𝑛𝑡subscriptΩ0superscriptsubscript𝑑subscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝑘𝑛𝜅subscriptℎ0h_{\tilde{k}_{n},k_{n}}^{(t)}=\sqrt{\Omega_{0}d_{\tilde{k}_{n},k_{n}}^{-\kappa}}h_{0} and hkn(t)=Ω0​dk~n,kn−κ​h0superscriptsubscriptℎsubscript𝑘𝑛𝑡subscriptΩ0superscriptsubscript𝑑subscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝑘𝑛𝜅subscriptℎ0h_{k_{n}}^{(t)}=\sqrt{\Omega_{0}d_{\tilde{k}_{n},k_{n}}^{-\kappa}}h_{0}, where dk~n,knsubscript𝑑subscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝑘𝑛d_{\tilde{k}_{n},k_{n}} and dknsubscript𝑑subscript𝑘𝑛d_{k_{n}} denote the distances between subordinate device k~nsubscript~𝑘𝑛\tilde{k}_{n} and its associated lead device knsubscript𝑘𝑛k_{n} and between the lead device knsubscript𝑘𝑛k_{n} to the PS, Ω0=−37subscriptΩ037\Omega_{0}=-37 dB is the path-loss at a reference distance of one meter, κ=3.5𝜅3.5\kappa=3.5 denotes the path-loss exponent, and h0subscriptℎ0h_{0} captures the small-scale fading of the channels and is i.i.d. across different iterations following the Rayleigh fading, i.e., h0∼𝒞​𝒩​(0,1)similar-tosubscriptℎ0𝒞𝒩01h_{0}\sim\mathcal{CN}(0,1). We consider the devices are i.i.d. distributed over a ring centered at the PS, where the inner radius is 150 m and the outer radius is 200 m222We do not consider the case that devices are uniformly distributed in the circle centered at the PS, since the devices close to the PS, i.e., the devices distributed in the nearby circle around the PS, are supposed to directly communicate to the PS without communicating to lead devices first. Hence, to focus on the considered two-tier scheme, we only consider the scenario that the devices are distributed at the network edge.. The learning rate is set as γ=1100​L𝛾1100𝐿\gamma=\frac{1}{100L}, where L𝐿L is empirically set as L=10𝐿10L=10 [41]. We consider balanced data size setting as Dk=60000Ksubscript𝐷𝑘60000𝐾D_{k}=\frac{60000}{K} with K=50𝐾50K=50 devices. Unless stated otherwise, the number of clusters is set as N=5𝑁5N=5, the noise power is set as σkn2=σ2=−80superscriptsubscript𝜎subscript𝑘𝑛2superscript𝜎280\sigma_{k_{n}}^{2}=\sigma^{2}=-80 dBm and the maximum power budget is set as Pkmax=0.2superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘max0.2P_{k}^{\rm max}=0.2 W, ∀kfor-all𝑘\forall k.

To achieve the image classification task, we aim to train a CNN as the classifier model, which consists of three 3×3333\times 3 convolution layers (each with 8, 16, and 32 channels, respectively), each followed by a 2×2222\times 2 max pooling layer with stride 2; fully connected layer with 10 units; and finally a softmax output layer. All convolutional layers are also followed by batch normalization layers and mapped by ReLU activation.

For performance comparison, we consider the following baseline schemes:

  • •

    Static clustering scheme: In this scheme, the devices are divided into clusters only based on their locations. Hence, the clustering result is static across all iterations, and this clustering scheme only accounts for the communication aspect of the considered two-tier wireless FL scheme. Given the clustering result, we obtain the transmit power control and de-noising factor by Algorithm 1.

  • •

    Gradient similarity-based clustering scheme: In this scheme, the devices are divided into clusters based on the cosine similarity of their gradients [44]. The clustering results are still dynamic across the training iterations, and this clustering scheme only accounts for the learning aspect of the considered two-tier wireless FL scheme. Similarly, given the clustering result, we obtain the transmit power control and de-noising factor by Algorithm 1.

  • •

    Maximum power transmissions scheme: In this scheme, the devices use their full transmit power to transmit their gradients. For subordinate device k~n∈𝒞n,∀nsubscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝒞𝑛for-all𝑛\tilde{k}_{n}\in\mathcal{C}_{n},\forall n, its transmit power is set as αk~n=Pk~nmaxsubscript𝛼subscript~𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑃subscript~𝑘𝑛max\alpha_{\tilde{k}_{n}}=P_{\tilde{k}_{n}}^{\rm max}, and the transmit power for lead device kn∈𝒞n,∀nsubscript𝑘𝑛subscript𝒞𝑛for-all𝑛k_{n}\in\mathcal{C}_{n},\forall n, is set as βkn=Pknmax/(∑k~n∈𝒞nh¯k~n,kn2​αk~n+σkn2)subscript𝛽subscript𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑃subscript𝑘𝑛maxsubscriptsubscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝒞𝑛superscriptsubscript¯ℎsubscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝑘𝑛2subscript𝛼subscript~𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜎subscript𝑘𝑛2\beta_{k_{n}}=P_{k_{n}}^{\rm max}/\left(\sum_{\tilde{k}_{n}\in\mathcal{C}_{n}}\bar{h}_{\tilde{k}_{n},k_{n}}^{2}\alpha_{\tilde{k}_{n}}+\sigma_{k_{n}}^{2}\right).

  • •

    Direct gradient transmission scheme: In this scheme, the devices directly transmit their gradients to the PS based on AirComp, and the transmit power and de-noising factor are obtained by solving the corresponding optimization problem similar to Problem (34).

  • •

    Conventional MSE minimization scheme: In this scheme, we directly minimize the MSE w.r.t. the normalized symbol 𝐬k(t)superscriptsubscript𝐬𝑘𝑡\mathbf{s}_{k}^{(t)} [26, 42].

V-B I.i.d. data distribution case

In this subsection, we evaluate the performance of the proposed scheme for the i.i.d. data distribution case, where we randomly assign the training samples to each device.

Fig. 2 compares the performances of all the schemes w.r.t. the iteration in terms of test accuracy with i.i.d. data distribution. It is observed that all the schemes converge after sufficiently larger number of iterations. When converges, the test accuracy of the proposed scheme is higher than those of the rest baseline schemes, while it performs close to the static clustering scheme. The reason why the proposed and static clustering schemes achieve close learning performance is that the data importance of the devices are quite close with i.i.d. data distribution. Hence, devices’ locations dominate the clustering objective when applying the hierarchical clustering method and the proposed clustering method is nearly static during the training process.

Fig. 3 compares the performances of all the schemes w.r.t. the number of cluster (i.e., N𝑁N) in terms of the average test accuracy when they converge with i.i.d. data distribution. It is observed that all the accuracies of the schemes that adopt the two-tier structures (i.e., excluding the direct gradient transmission scheme) first increase and then decrease with the number of clusters. The reason why these schemes suffer from performance losses when N𝑁N is small is that lead devices are required to aggregate a large number of subordinate devices, even when the subordinate devices are far away from the associated lead devices. In this case, the subordinate devices with relatively large distances to the lead device suffer from bad channel fading, and the transmit power of the lead device is limited since they need to aggregate too many gradients from the subordinate devices. The reason why these schemes suffer from performance losses when the number of cluster becomes large is that larger N𝑁N results in less data exploitation, since the lead devices only account for relaying the aggregated gradients and do not upload their gradients to the PS. For different numbers of clusters, i.e., 2≤N≤102𝑁102\leq N\leq 10, the static clustering scheme achieves close learning performance to the proposed scheme due the same reason as explained in Fig. 2. The accuracy of the proposed scheme is always much higher than the gradient-similarity based clustering, maximum transmission power, and conventional MSE schemes, and is higher than the direct gradient transmission scheme when N>2𝑁2N>2.

Fig. 4 compares the performances of all the schemes w.r.t. different levels of maximum transmit power budget Pkmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘maxP_{k}^{\rm max}, in terms of the average test accuracy when they converge with i.i.d. data distribution. It is observed that the test accuracies of all schemes excluding the maximum power transmit scheme increase with with the maximum transmit power budget, while the test accuracy of the maximum power transmission scheme first increases and then decreases with the maximum transmit power budget. This is due to fact that gradient misalignment error is quite large when the devices always transmit with sufficiently large transmit power. Obviously, the proposed scheme outperforms the rest baseline schemes and the static clustering scheme achieves close performance to the proposed scheme for different levels of Pkmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘maxP_{k}^{\rm max}. Besides, with sufficiently large transmit power budget, i.e., Pkmax=1superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘max1P_{k}^{\rm max}=1 W, the direct gradient transmission scheme achieves comparable test accuracy to the proposed scheme. This is because when Pkmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘maxP_{k}^{\rm max} is sufficiently large, both these two schemes exhibit optimal channel inversion power control and the noise-induced errors can be suppressed into relatively low levels for both of them due to the de-noising factor.

V-C Non-i.i.d. data distribution case

In this subsection, we evaluate the performance of the proposed scheme for the non-i.i.d. data distribution case, where we split the training samples into 5 disjoint subsets with each subset containing 2 classes of images, and each subset is chose to randomly assign training samples to K/5𝐾5K/5 devices. Hence, each device only contains two classes of images and different devices contains different classes of images.

Fig. 5 compares the performances of all the schemes w.r.t. the number of iterations in terms of test accuracy with non-i.i.d. data distribution. It is observed that all the schemes still converge after sufficient large number of iterations and the proposed scheme also outperforms the baseline schemes in terms of convergence rate and test accuracy. Besides, compared to the i.i.d data distribution case in (2), all the schemes suffer from performance loss, and the test accuracy for the proposed scheme when converges is significantly higher than that of the static clustering scheme, which shows the effectiveness of the joint consideration of device distance and data importance for clustering under the non-i.i.d. data distribution case. Besides, the increasing trends of all the schemes become less stable compared to those in the i.i.d. data distribution case, which is obviously caused by the non-i.i.d. data distribution.

Fig. 6 compares the performances of all the schemes w.r.t. different number of cluster N𝑁N in terms of the average test accuracy when they converge with non-i.i.d. data distribution. Similar to the i.i.d. data distribution case, the accuracies of all the schemes that adopt the two-tier structures first increase and then decrease with the number of clusters and the accuracy of the proposed scheme is always much higher than the rest two-tier baseline schemes. When the number of clusters is quite small, i.e., N=2𝑁2N=2, the accuracy of the proposed scheme is slightly lower than that of the direct gradient transmission scheme due to the same reason as explained for the case shown in Fig. 3. When the number of clusters N𝑁N becomes large, i.e., N=10𝑁10N=10, the proposed scheme not only suffer from performance loss compared to the case when N𝑁N is moderate, i.e., 4≤N≤84𝑁84\leq N\leq 8, but also has lower test accuracy than the direct gradient transmission scheme, which is different to the case with i.i.d. data distribution case in Fig. 3. This is due to the fact that the negative effect of insufficient data exploitation becomes much more severe for the non-i.i.d. data distribution case.

Fig. 7 compares the performances of all the schemes w.r.t. different levels of maximum transmit power budget Pkmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘maxP_{k}^{\rm max} in terms of the average test accuracy, when they converge with non-i.i.d. data distribution. Similar to the i.i.d. data distribution case in Fig. 4, the test accuracies of all the proposed schemes excluding the maximum power transmission scheme increase with the maximum transmit power budget. The test accuracy of the maximum power transmission scheme first increases and then decreases with the maximum power budget, and the test accuracy with sufficiently large power budget is even lower than that with small power budget. This is due to the negative effects of both the large gradient misalignment error with sufficiently high transmit power and insufficient data exploitation with non-i.i.d data distribution. Besides, different from the case with i.i.d. data distribution, with sufficiently large transmit power budget, i.e., Pkmax=1superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘max1P_{k}^{\rm max}=1 W, the direct gradient transmission scheme has slightly higher test accuracy compared to the proposed scheme. This is because the proposed scheme still suffers from negative effect of insufficient data exploitation while the direct gradient transmission scheme does not. Such negative effect is much more severe in the non-i.i.d. data distribution case compared to the i.i.d. data distribution case. However, the proposed scheme outperforms all the baseline schemes when the transmit power budget is not sufficiently large enough.

VI Conclusion

In this paper, we studied the joint communication and learning design for an AirComp-based two-tier wireless FL scheme, where all devices are dynamically partitioned into different clusters across different training iterations and the PS aggregates the gradients from the devices through AirComp-based intra-cluster and inter-cluster gradient aggregations. First, we analyzed the convergence behavior of the proposed scheme and the optimality gap between the expected and optimal global loss values was derived under mild conditions. The optimality gap characterized the impact of the AirComp-based two-tier gradient aggregation errors on the convergence of the proposed scheme, which needs to be minimized to enhance the performance of the proposed scheme. To this end, we proposed the clustering method and studied optimality gap minimization problem. By jointly considering the device distance and data importance as the minimax linkage criterion, we proposed a low-complexity hierarchical clustering method that can be efficiently implemented during the training process. Then, with the instantaneous CSI and clustering result in each iteration, we formulated the optimality gap minimization problem under the individual transmit power constraint. To solve the optimization problem, we proposed an alternating minimization method, where the optimal solution for the subordinate devices follows regularized composite channel inversion structure. Finally, numerical results showed that our proposed scheme outperforms the baseline schemes.

≤\displaystyle\leq (2​L2​γ2−L​γ)​(F​(𝐰(t))−F∗)+L​γ2mb​‖𝝈‖2+γ2​‖𝔼​[𝜺(t)]‖2+L​γ2​𝔼​[‖𝜺(t)‖2].2superscript𝐿2superscript𝛾2𝐿𝛾𝐹superscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐹𝐿superscript𝛾2subscript𝑚𝑏superscriptnorm𝝈2𝛾2superscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝜺𝑡2𝐿superscript𝛾2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscript𝜺𝑡2\displaystyle(2L^{2}\gamma^{2}-L\gamma)\left(F(\mathbf{w}^{(t)})-F^{*}\right)+\frac{L\gamma^{2}}{m_{b}}\|\bm{\sigma}\|^{2}+\frac{\gamma}{2}\left\|\mathbb{E}\left[\bm{\varepsilon}^{(t)}\right]\right\|^{2}+L\gamma^{2}\mathbb{E}\left[\|\bm{\varepsilon}^{(t)}\|^{2}\right]. (53)

Through some further algebraic manipulation, we obtain

+L​γ2mb​‖𝝈‖2+γ2​‖𝔼​[𝜺(t)]‖2+L​γ2​𝔼​[‖𝜺(t)‖2].𝐿superscript𝛾2subscript𝑚𝑏superscriptnorm𝝈2𝛾2superscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝜺𝑡2𝐿superscript𝛾2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscript𝜺𝑡2\displaystyle+\frac{L\gamma^{2}}{m_{b}}\|\bm{\sigma}\|^{2}+\frac{\gamma}{2}\left\|\mathbb{E}\left[\bm{\varepsilon}^{(t)}\right]\right\|^{2}+L\gamma^{2}\mathbb{E}\left[\|\bm{\varepsilon}^{(t)}\|^{2}\right]. (54)

Assume the FL algorithm terminates after T𝑇T rounds. Given an initial global model 𝐰(1)superscript𝐰1\mathbf{w}^{(1)}, by carrying out recursions for (A), Theorem 1 is proved.

Appendix B Proof of Proposition 1

Since problem (36) is convex and satisfies the Slater’s condition, strong duality holds between problem (36) and its Lagrange dual problem [45]. Let λk~nsubscript𝜆subscript~𝑘𝑛\lambda_{\tilde{k}_{n}} and μnsubscript𝜇𝑛\mu_{n} denote the dual variables associated with the k~nsubscript~𝑘𝑛\tilde{k}_{n}-th constraint in (36b) and the n𝑛n-th constraint in (36c), respectively. Hence, the Lagrange of of problem (36) is given as

ℒ=ℒabsent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}= ∑n=1N∑k~n∈𝒞n(c1​(ζ​h¯kn​βkn​h¯k~n,kn​α¯k~n−1)2+λk~n​α¯k~n)+∑n=1N∑k~n∈𝒞n,k~n≠knμn​h¯k~n,kn2​α¯k~n2+∑n=1Nμn​σkn2superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscriptsubscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝒞𝑛subscript𝑐1superscript𝜁subscript¯ℎsubscript𝑘𝑛subscript𝛽subscript𝑘𝑛subscript¯ℎsubscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝑘𝑛subscript¯𝛼subscript~𝑘𝑛12subscript𝜆subscript~𝑘𝑛subscript¯𝛼subscript~𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscriptformulae-sequencesubscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝒞𝑛subscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝑘𝑛subscript𝜇𝑛superscriptsubscript¯ℎsubscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝑘𝑛2superscriptsubscript¯𝛼subscript~𝑘𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝜇𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜎subscript𝑘𝑛2\displaystyle\sum_{n=1}^{N}\sum_{\tilde{k}_{n}\in\mathcal{C}_{n}}\left(c_{1}\left(\zeta\bar{h}_{k_{n}}\sqrt{\beta_{k_{n}}}\bar{h}_{\tilde{k}_{n},k_{n}}\bar{\alpha}_{\tilde{k}_{n}}-1\right)^{2}+\lambda_{\tilde{k}_{n}}\bar{\alpha}_{\tilde{k}_{n}}\right)+\sum_{n=1}^{N}\sum_{\tilde{k}_{n}\in\mathcal{C}_{n},\tilde{k}_{n}\neq k_{n}}\mu_{n}\bar{h}_{\tilde{k}_{n},k_{n}}^{2}\bar{\alpha}_{\tilde{k}_{n}}^{2}+\sum_{n=1}^{N}\mu_{n}\sigma_{k_{n}}^{2}
−∑n=1N∑k~n∈𝒞nλk~n​Pk~nmax−∑n=1Nμn​P¯knmax.superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscriptsubscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝒞𝑛subscript𝜆subscript~𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑃subscript~𝑘𝑛maxsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝜇𝑛superscriptsubscript¯𝑃subscript𝑘𝑛max\displaystyle-\sum_{n=1}^{N}\sum_{\tilde{k}_{n}\in\mathcal{C}_{n}}\lambda_{\tilde{k}_{n}}\sqrt{P_{\tilde{k}_{n}}^{\rm max}}-\sum_{n=1}^{N}\mu_{n}\bar{P}_{k_{n}}^{\rm max}. (55)

Then, the optimal primal and dual variables satisfy the Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) optimality conditions, which are given as

α¯k~n∗≤Pk~nmax,k~n∈𝒞n,∀n,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript¯𝛼subscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝑃superscriptsubscript~𝑘𝑛maxsubscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝒞𝑛for-all𝑛\displaystyle\bar{\alpha}_{\tilde{k}_{n}}^{*}\leq\sqrt{P_{\tilde{k}_{n}^{\rm max}}},\ \tilde{k}_{n}\in\mathcal{C}_{n},\forall n, (56)
∑k~n∈𝒞nh¯k~n,kn2​(α¯k~n∗)2+σkn2≤P¯knmax,∀n,subscriptsubscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝒞𝑛superscriptsubscript¯ℎsubscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝑘𝑛2superscriptsuperscriptsubscript¯𝛼subscript~𝑘𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝜎subscript𝑘𝑛2superscriptsubscript¯𝑃subscript𝑘𝑛maxfor-all𝑛\displaystyle\sum_{\tilde{k}_{n}\in\mathcal{C}_{n}}\bar{h}_{\tilde{k}_{n},k_{n}}^{2}\left(\bar{\alpha}_{\tilde{k}_{n}}^{*}\right)^{2}+\sigma_{k_{n}}^{2}\leq\bar{P}_{k_{n}}^{\rm max},\forall n, (57)
λk~n∗≥0,∀k~n∈𝒦∖𝒦N,μn∗≥0,n=1,⋯,N,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝜆subscript~𝑘𝑛0formulae-sequencefor-allsubscript~𝑘𝑛𝒦subscript𝒦𝑁formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑛0𝑛1⋯𝑁\displaystyle\lambda_{\tilde{k}_{n}}^{*}\geq 0,\forall\tilde{k}_{n}\in\mathcal{K}\setminus\mathcal{K}_{N},\mu_{n}^{*}\geq 0,n=1,\cdots,N, (58)
λk~n∗​(α¯k~n∗−Pk~nmax)=0,k~n∈𝒞n,∀n,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝜆subscript~𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript¯𝛼subscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝑃superscriptsubscript~𝑘𝑛max0subscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝒞𝑛for-all𝑛\displaystyle\lambda_{\tilde{k}_{n}}^{*}\left(\bar{\alpha}_{\tilde{k}_{n}}^{*}-\sqrt{P_{\tilde{k}_{n}^{\rm max}}}\right)=0,\tilde{k}_{n}\in\mathcal{C}_{n},\forall n, (59)
μn∗​(∑k~n∈𝒞nh¯k~n,kn2​(α¯k~n∗)2+σkn2−P¯knmax)=0,∀n,superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑛subscriptsubscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝒞𝑛superscriptsubscript¯ℎsubscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝑘𝑛2superscriptsuperscriptsubscript¯𝛼subscript~𝑘𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝜎subscript𝑘𝑛2superscriptsubscript¯𝑃subscript𝑘𝑛max0for-all𝑛\displaystyle\mu_{n}^{*}\left(\sum_{\tilde{k}_{n}\in\mathcal{C}_{n}}\bar{h}_{\tilde{k}_{n},k_{n}}^{2}\left(\bar{\alpha}_{\tilde{k}_{n}}^{*}\right)^{2}+\sigma_{k_{n}}^{2}-\bar{P}_{k_{n}}^{\rm max}\right)=0,\forall n, (60)

(61)

Based on the KKT optimality conditions, we obtain the optimal solution α¯k~n∗superscriptsubscript¯𝛼subscript~𝑘𝑛\bar{\alpha}_{\tilde{k}_{n}}^{*} to problem (36) as

α¯k~n∗=min⁡[c1​ζ​h¯kn​βkn,2​h¯k~n,knc1​ζ2​h¯kn2​βkn​h¯k~n,kn2+μn∗​h¯k~n,kn2,Pk~nmax],superscriptsubscript¯𝛼subscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝑐1𝜁subscript¯ℎsubscript𝑘𝑛subscript𝛽subscript𝑘𝑛2subscript¯ℎsubscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝑘𝑛subscript𝑐1superscript𝜁2superscriptsubscript¯ℎsubscript𝑘𝑛2subscript𝛽subscript𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript¯ℎsubscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝑘𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑛superscriptsubscript¯ℎsubscript~𝑘𝑛subscript𝑘𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝑃subscript~𝑘𝑛max\displaystyle\bar{\alpha}_{\tilde{k}_{n}}^{*}=\min\left[\frac{c_{1}\zeta\bar{h}_{k_{n}}\sqrt{\beta_{k_{n},2}}\bar{h}_{\tilde{k}_{n},k_{n}}}{c_{1}\zeta^{2}\bar{h}_{k_{n}}^{2}\beta_{k_{n}}\bar{h}_{\tilde{k}_{n},k_{n}}^{2}+\mu_{n}^{*}\bar{h}_{\tilde{k}_{n},k_{n}}^{2}},\sqrt{P_{\tilde{k}_{n}}^{\rm max}}\right], (62)

where non-negative {μn∗}superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑛\{\mu_{n}^{*}\} satisfies the complementary slackness conditions in (60). Hence, the optimal solution αk~noptsuperscriptsubscript𝛼subscript~𝑘𝑛opt\alpha_{\tilde{k}_{n}}^{\rm opt} to problem (35) is given as αk~nopt=(α¯k~n∗)2superscriptsubscript𝛼subscript~𝑘𝑛optsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript¯𝛼subscript~𝑘𝑛2\alpha_{\tilde{k}_{n}}^{\rm opt}=\left(\bar{\alpha}_{\tilde{k}_{n}}^{*}\right)^{2}, as shown in (37). This thus completes the proof.
